para.sentence: The six Painlevé equations \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are as follows: \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=6w^{2}+z, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=2w^{3}+zw+\alpha, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=\frac{1}{w}\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}w }{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+\frac{ \alpha w^{2}+\beta}{z}+\gamma w^{3}+\frac{\delta}{w},
with \alpha , \beta , \gamma , and \delta arbitrary constants.
The solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are called the Painlevé transcendents.
The six equations are sometimes referred to as the Painlevé transcendents, but in this chapter this term will be used only for their solutions.

Let \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=F\left(z,w,\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{ \mathrm{d}z}\right), be a nonlinear second-order differential equation in which F is a rational function of w and \ifrac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} , and is locally analytic in z , that is, analytic except for isolated singularities in \mathbb{C}.
In general the singularities of the solutions are movable in the sense that their location depends on the constants of integration associated with the initial orboundary conditions.

An equation is said to have the Painlevé property if all its solutions are free from movable branch points; the solutions may have movable poles or movable isolated essential singularities (§1.10(iii)), however.
There are fifty equations with the Painlevé property.
They are distinct modulo Möbius (bilinear) transformations W(\zeta)=\frac{a(z)w+b(z)}{c(z)w+d(z)},\zeta=\phi(z), in which a(z) , b(z) , c(z) , d(z) , and \phi(z) are locally analytic functions.

The fifty equations can be reduced to linear equations, solved in terms of elliptic functions (Chapters 22 and 23), or reduced to one of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}.

For arbitrary values of the parameters \alpha , \beta , \gamma , and \delta , the general solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are transcendental, that is, they cannot be expressed in closed-form elementary functions.

However, for special values of the parameters, equations \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} have special solutions in terms of elementary functions, or special functions defined elsewhere in the DLMF.
If \gamma\delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , then set \gamma=1 and \delta=-1 , without loss of generality, by rescaling w and z if necessary.
If \gamma=0 and \alpha\delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , then set \alpha=1 and \delta=-1 , without loss of generality.
Lastly, if \delta=0 and \beta\gamma\neq 0 , then set \beta=-1 and \gamma=1 , without loss ofgenerality.
If \delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , then set \delta=-\tfrac{1}{2} , without loss of generality.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , if w(z)=\zeta^{-1/2}u(\zeta) with \zeta=z^{2} , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=\frac{1}{u}\left(\frac{\mathrm {d}u}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d} \zeta}+\frac{u^{2}(\alpha+\gamma u)}{4\zeta^{2}}+\frac{\beta}{4\zeta}+\frac{ \delta}{4u}, which is known as \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , if w(z)=\exp\left(-iu(z)\right) , \beta=-\alpha , and \delta=-\gamma , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\frac{1}{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{ \mathrm{d}z}=\frac{2\alpha}{z}\sin u+2\gamma\sin\left(2u\right).

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} , if w(z)=2\sqrt{2}(u(\zeta))^{2} with \zeta=\sqrt{2}z and \alpha=2\nu+1 , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=3u^{5}+2\zeta u^{3}+\left( \tfrac{1}{4}\zeta^{2}-\nu-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)u+\frac{\beta}{32u^{3}}.
When \beta=0 this is a nonlinear harmonic oscillator.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , if w(z)=(\coth u(\zeta))^{2} with \zeta=\ln z , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=-\frac{\alpha\cosh u}{2(\sinh u )^{3}}-\frac{\beta\sinh u}{2(\cosh u)^{3}}-\tfrac{1}{4}\gamma e^{\zeta}\sinh \left(2u\right)-\tfrac{1}{8}\delta e^{2\zeta}\sinh\left(4u\right).
See also Okamoto (1987c), McCoy et al. (1977),Bassom et al. (1992), Bassom et al. (1995), andTakasaki (2001).

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} can be written in the form z(1-z)I\left(\int_{\infty}^{w}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t(t-1)(t-z)}}\right)= \sqrt{w(w-1)(w-z)}\*\left(\alpha+\frac{\beta z}{w^{2}}+\frac{\gamma(z-1)}{(w-1 )^{2}}+(\delta-\tfrac{1}{2})\frac{z(z-1)}{(w-z)^{2}}\right), where I=z(1-z)\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(1-2z)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{ \mathrm{d}z}-\frac{1}{4}.
See Fuchs (1907), Painlevé (1906),Gromak et al. (2002, §42); also Manin (1998).

Let \frac{\mathrm{d}f_{1}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{1}(f_{2}-f_{3})+2\mu_{1}=0,\frac{\mathrm{d}f_{2}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{2}(f_{3}-f_{1})+2\mu_{2}=0,\frac{\mathrm{d}f_{3}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{3}(f_{1}-f_{2})+2\mu_{3}=0, where \mu_{1} , \mu_{2} , \mu_{3} are constants, f_{1} , f_{2} , f_{3} are functions of z , with \mu_{1}+\mu_{2}+\mu_{3}=1, f_{1}(z)+f_{2}(z)+f_{3}(z)+2z=0.
Then w(z)=f_{1}(z) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with (\alpha,\beta)=(\mu_{3}-\mu_{2},-2\mu_{1}^{2}).
See Noumi and Yamada (1998).
Then w(z)=1-(\sqrt{z}/f_{1}(z)) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu_{1}^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu_{3}^{2} ,\mu_{4}-\mu_{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}).

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are obtained from \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} by a coalescence cascade: \begin{array}[]{ccccccc}\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}$}& \longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox {$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}}$}\\ &&\big{\downarrow}&&\big{\downarrow}\\ &&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{ \mbox{\scriptsize II}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I} }$}\end{array}

For example, if in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} w(z;\alpha)=\epsilon W(\zeta)+\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5}}, z=\epsilon^{2}\zeta-\frac{6}{\epsilon^{10}},\alpha=\frac{4}{\epsilon^{15}}, then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=6W^{2}+\zeta+\epsilon^{6}(2W^{ 3}+\zeta W); thus in the limit as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} with z=\zeta.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=1+2\epsilon W(\zeta;a), z=1+\epsilon^{2}\zeta,\alpha=-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6},\beta=\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6}+2a\epsilon^{-3},\gamma=-\delta=\tfrac{1}{4}\epsilon^{-6}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} w(z;\alpha,\beta)=2^{2/3}\epsilon^{-1}W(\zeta;a)+\epsilon^{-3}, z=2^{-2/3}\epsilon\zeta-\epsilon^{-3},\alpha=-2a-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6},\beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-12}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=1+\epsilon\zeta W(\zeta;a,b,c,d), z=\zeta^{2},\alpha=\tfrac{1}{4}a\epsilon^{-1}+\tfrac{1}{8}c\epsilon^{-2},\beta=-\tfrac{1}{8}c\epsilon^{-2},\gamma=\tfrac{1}{4}\epsilon b,\delta=\tfrac{1}{8}\epsilon^{2}d, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b,c,d) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b , \gamma=c , \delta=d.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{2}\epsilon W(\zeta;a,b), z=1+\sqrt{2}\epsilon\zeta,\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-4},\beta=\tfrac{1}{4}b,\gamma=-\epsilon^{-4},\delta=a\epsilon^{-2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-4}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b.

Lastly, if in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=W(\zeta;a,b,c,d), z=1+\epsilon\zeta,\gamma=c\epsilon^{-1}-d\epsilon^{-2},\delta=d\epsilon^{-2}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b,c,d) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b , \gamma=c , \delta=d.
